computer.description:
LX-500 series were first microcomputers from Logabax, a French computers manufacturer specialized in small and medium size computers aimed at private and state-owned companies.
It was a stange looking small metal box containing a single multifunction Z80 based card and two 90 KB 5.25" floppy drives. A serial port allowed the Logabax video terminal to be connected. A few months later, several versions appeared (LX-525, LX-528) featuring a cheap plastic case, but 710 KB floppy drives and two extra Serial ports. The system ran Logabax DOS and a flavour of CP/M Operating System.
In fact, due to its very expensive price for the time (about 4000 Euros) the LX-500 never met success near private companies despite Logabax efforts in setting up an European dealers network.
However, at this time French ministry of education sought french computers to equip thousands of high schools. Only two French manufacturers were able to provide such small systems: R2E (with its 80-20 series) and Logabax. Thus Logabax got more than half the ministry contract and several thousands systems were installed in classrooms, even though the system was far to meet reliability and ease of use requested in educational environment.
The LX-500 was one of the first machines with which French students could learn LSE language (Symbolic Language for Education), a structured evolution of the BASIC language, with French keywords, intended to be the universal language for students and academics. However, student liked PASCAL and Microsoft BASIC better than LSE, and the language quickly sank into oblivion.
Despite Logabax had priviligied access to procurement contracts with French state, the company met serious cash shortage problems. After several vain attempts from French government to refloat the company, Logabax was eventually sold to Olivetti, the first Italian computers company. After some common ventures (Olivetti-Logabax Persona PC systems), Logabax finally disappeared for good. _______________________

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METAL CASE WITH TERMINAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>First LX-529 version along with the LX-450 video terminal</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PLASTIC CASE WITH TERMINAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>LX-539 version along with terminal. Notice the original Logabax diskette.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LX-529 BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apart from the serial terminal connector <b>(2)</b>, only one Parallel printer connector <b>(1)</b> was available. There was no possibilty to add further expansion connectors.<br> <b>(3)</b> Power switch.<br><br> Notice the metal label mentioning that this system was the property of French Ministry of education.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LX-539 BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>In addition to Terminal <b>(2)</b> and Parallel <b>(1)</b> ports, later models featured two extra serial port <b>(3)</b> and an internal connector for dual FDD or 5 MB hard disk unit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A very simple internal design:<br> - One main board<br> - Two floppy drives<br> - One power supply unit<br><br> Notice that all the components are not fixed to the case and can be easily removed.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN BOARD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>First main board didn't feature floppy disc controller chipset. Standard 74XX chips was used for FD management.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Z80 processor, here a MOSTEK version<br> <b>(2)</b> 2 x 8250 I/O chips<br> <b>(3)</b> 16 KB of RAM was mounted on board. An optional 16 KB piggyback card could be added<br> <b>(4)</b> Terminal and Parallel connectors<br> <b>(5)</b> IPL (Initial Program Loader) 2 KB ROM chip</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN BOARD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Second main board version.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Terminal and Parallel connectors<br> <b>(2)</b> Z80 CTC, clock and timer chipset<br> <b>(3)</b> First additional serial port<br> <b>(4)</b> Z80 processor<br> <b>(5)</b> 2 x 8250 I/O chips<br> <b>(6)</b> Second additional serial port<br> <b>(7)</b> IPL 2 KB ROM chip<br> <b>(8)</b> 8 x 4864 RAM chips hold 64 KB of RAM. A piggyback 64 KB RAM card could be added<br> <b>(9)</b> Floppy drives controller connector<br> <b>(10)</b> Western Digital FDD and hard disk controller chipset<br> <b>(11)</b> Power LED and reset switch<br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>64 KB RAM chips, Z80 processor and IPL ROM. <br> Original ROM had to be changed to run CP/M operating system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE TERMINAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>LX-450 terminal featured:<br> - A 15" CRT (rare at the time)<br> - A Z80 processor<br> - 2 x Intel I/O chips<br> - 2 KB of video RAM<br> - 2 KB of program ROM<br> - 4 KB of ROM for characters generator. </blockquote>
